conclusion: We have an incident ray of blue light traveling from point A in the air towards the water-air boundary. The point where the ray intersects the boundary is denoted as O1. After refraction, the ray continues to travel in the water and passes through point B. The problem asks if the point O1 is to the right of the intersection point O (where line AB meets the boundary).

When light travels from air to water, it bends towards the normal due to Snell's law: n_air sin(θ_i) = n_water sin(θ_r) where θ_i is the angle of incidence in air, θ_r is the angle of refraction in water, n_air is the refractive index of air (approximately 1), and n_water is the refractive index of water (approximately 1.33).
From the diagram provided, the incident ray comes from A and strikes the boundary at O1. The refracted ray passes through B. The point O is the intersection of the line AB with the boundary.

premise: Since the light bends towards the normal when entering water, the refracted ray will be closer to the normal compared to the incident ray.
conclusion: The actual path taken by the light (AO1B) will be such that the point O1 is to the left of the geometric projection point O because the refracted ray must bend inward.

premise: If O1 were to the right of O, it would violate the principle of light bending towards the normal.
conclusion: O1 must be to the left of O.
